As we‚Äôve seen, the effects of systemic segregation directly correlate with a lack of resources available for our children's education.

These policies don't just impact the lives of our children, they have generational consequences.

We cannot allow this to happen. Separate is not equal.

We must stand up and fight for equal funding, equal educational outcomes, and the support necessary to make sure our students are not being placed into a new system of separate and unequal schools.

But why is this still happening? 

The report points to changing school district boundaries that move students into predominantly same-race schools based on where they live. In short, shifting school district boundaries contribute to continued divisions along racial/ethnic lines. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FYNcm43XgAcfWA-.png

This "grouping" has had generational effects on how school district boundaries are drawn, and its effects could not be clearer.
¬†

Nationally, we‚Äôre seeing an increase in school districts breaking down along racial lines‚Äîa remnant of redlining and discrimination.

When banks refused to lend to minority families, they limited the ability of communities to integrate, splitting neighborhoods among racial lines.

School segregation leads to unequal resources & opportunities for students.
¬†
Brown v. Board said it.
Teachers know it.
¬†
